content: The Act titled "Federal Labor-Management Partnership Act of 2018" establishes the Federal Labor-Management Partnership Council. The "Federal Labor-Management Partnership Act of 2018" establishes the Federal Labor-Management Partnership Council, composed of key government officials including the Director of the Office of Personnel Management and the Chairman of the Federal Labor Relations Authority. The Federal Labor-Management Partnership Act of 2018 establishes the Federal Labor-Management Partnership Council, which includes the Director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, 2 members appointed by the President to represent the largest labor organizations, and 4 members appointed to represent labor organizations with substantial numbers of employees. The Federal Labor-Management Partnership Council includes members appointed by the President to represent various labor organizations, senior executives, and management officials. The Council advises the President on labor-management relations in the executive branch. The Federal Labor-Management Partnership Council supports partnership efforts in the executive branch by creating local labor-management councils, collecting and sharing information, and utilizing expertise to foster partnerships. The Council is co-chaired by the Director of the Office of Personnel Management and the Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget, meeting quarterly or as needed. The Federal Labor-Management Partnership Council seeks input from various agencies, experts, and stakeholders, including companies, nonprofit organizations, and state and local governments. The Office of Personnel Management can provide staff and facilities upon request, subject to legal constraints and funding availability. Management shall provide staff, facilities, support, and administrative services to the Council as requested. Council members serve without compensation. Agencies must assist the Council as requested. Reporting to Congress is done by a co-chair. Members serve a 3-year term. The Council members serve a 3-year term, with the possibility of serving after the term expires for up to 60 days. Members appointed to fill vacancies serve the unexpired term of the replaced member. Non-employee members are not considered special Government employees. The Council established under the Federal Advisory Committee Act is not subject to termination. Section 7108 requires agencies to create labor-management partnerships by forming committees or councils, involving employees and representatives to improve civil service. Training must be provided systematically. The agency is required to provide training in dispute resolution methods and involve employees in workplace matters. They must also provide information to employee representatives and make a good-faith attempt to resolve issues regarding changes in employment conditions. The agency must engage in discussions with labor-management committees regarding proposed changes in employment conditions. They should also evaluate the impact of labor-management partnerships on organizational performance. The curr_chunk discusses the establishment of the Federal Labor-Management Partnership Council and the implementation of labor-management partnerships in the executive branch.
